149664305.review:
Interesting platformer. The controls are very simple, you move left and right, and use up and down to flip your character's gravity. Despite using so few buttons, the game offers several difficult and creative platforming challenges to be found. As you navigate the map in search of your lost crewmates, you will also find collectible trinkets (20 to find), adding an extra exploratory challenge on top of the main objective.

An aspect of this game that may make or break this game for people is how your playable character feels to control; Captain Viridian can feel a bit 'slippery' with how sensitive to your input he is. Most of the game is based on precision and timing so it can be a bit frustrating if you don't tolerate that too well, but otherwise it is a well aged indie that doesn't outstay its' welcome. 

Apart from the main story, there are additional challenges and time trials to enjoy, for those looking for something extra.

147779842.review:
VVVVVV is a really well-thought-out platformer with simple mechanics and level designs that make the most of them. Terry Cavanagh clearly knows how to introduce players to concepts, gradually building up from the very simple to the more advanced, keeping the player engaged as things get tough. VVVVVV does a really good job of hinting at solutions to various puzzles using room names (e.g. Prize for the Reckless) for those paying attention. The game is also good at hammering home the point that the trinkets are completely optional, so no-one wanting to just rescue the crewmates and reach the credits wastes time and effort.

Veridian controls really well, but not being so tight that the game becomes easy. His hitbox, and those of the various hazards, are pretty fair as well, so players shouldn't end up hating the game because of difficult passages, but rather their own motor skills.

The in-game map does a good job of helping you uncover everything you need and hints at how to get from A to B, since the wrap-around nature of the world doesn't always make this explicit.

On the whole, VVVVVV isn't difficult if you just want to reach the credits. Most of the challenge lies in collecting all the trinkets. And then for the die-hards, the Steam achievements command increasing levels of skill, right up to no-death mode. So players can choose their poison in that regard. There were a couple of moments that I thought should have been worthy of achievements (think Sad Elephant and Naughty Step) that were sadly missing, but I'll get over it.

Overall, definitely worth a go, and essential if you're into puzzle-platformers.

A classic among classics.
VVVVVV doesn't really need an introduction anymore – it's a platformer where you can't jump, but instead, you can reverse gravity. The game is indeed very short (around 1 hour), but every second spent in it is incredible, be it the gameplay, the music, or even just the minimalist graphics, which contribute greatly to creating a unique atmosphere.

If you're a platforming veteran, VVVVVV probably won't pose much of a challenge (it might be slightly difficult if you're not used to this genre, but nothing insurmountable), but it's an experience worth having in any case.

144296669.review:
(opens with him playing The Karate Kid)

This game, is ASS...

(gets defeated)

Fuck. Fuck! Fuck! Fuck. (in lower pitch) Fuuck! (in slow-mo, with the word coming out of his mouth) FUUUCK! (sticks the middle finger at the TV, drops controller, stutters) FUCK! (grabs TV and yells) DIIIIIIIIIIIIE! (in super-slow motion): FUUUUUUUUCKEEEEEEEEEEERS! (Cuts to him in his kitchen) You tried to help me now, man?! (shoves his head into a cabinet)

(shows the game cart to the viewers) Well, let me be honest with you about this one. Ooh boy, I HATE this game. I mean, it makes me wanna kill myself. Now, the only comforting thing to know is that everybody seems to share my frustration. Karate Kid is a game, that has haunted many of our childhoods. I mean, everybody has the same story: "I loved the movie, so I got the Nintendo game, and I couldn't stand it, yet I had to keep on playing it, because I had to beat it." So, what is it about this game, that's drawn so many unfortunate kids to turn into bitter adults, reminiscing on their angry childhood; screamin' at the TV, throwin' the controllers? I mean, anybody who has beaten this incredibly hard piece of shit will not have any sense of satisfaction but, rather regrets, because it is a complete waste of fuckin' time. I mean, it's like coming out of a brutal fight, being the winner, but achieving nothing for all your troubles but some bloody bruises and broken bones. It's just not worth it.

The biggest problem is that the control is so awkward. You have to press Up to jump, which doesn't really help because you can only go straight up in the air. He has... you ha-you gotta be like absolutely still, and if you touch an enemy, ya fly in the opposite direction. You can't get close enough to really attack anybody. You die in every pit and it's so easy to fall into them. So every time you get hit near a pit you're basically dead.

Level one is ridiculously easy. You just fight one-on-one and then you kick the shit outta everybody, and there you go, you win. Do it again, and again.

Now level two is where we get to the side-scrolling gameplay. It's almost a ripoff of Kung Fu, but much worse.

Every once in a while there's these stupid bonus stages which are next to impossible. Man, I think it's pretty safe to say that it would be easier to do this in real life.

Now when you get to level three, there's a typhoon, so the wind keeps pushin' ya back, and if that's not enough, there's these twigs and birds flyin' through the air. Every possible projectile hurts you and makes ya fly back, and there's pits everywhere.

I hate this game, but why am I playing it? Well, that's the question everyone has asked theirselves. And they all have the same reason: because you're angry and you wanna win. You wanna beat the Nintendo, but the cold fact is that nobody cares but you.

Then you get to level four and holy shit, is it hard. You can't get near anybody to attack them, and they all have these long spears that make ya fly back. You can sometimes hit people when you're walking uphill, but when you're goin' down, you can't really attack low enough to hit them. They're all basically just bullying up on ya, and they just knock ya all around and there's nothing you can do.

And guess what? That's the last level, and if you were expecting some big ending to be worth all your trouble, well you're wrong. The only thing that happens at the end is that Mr. Miyagi winks. What a piece of shit.

Man, I guess they decided because the game's only four levels long, it better be the hardest four levels ever. Well, how 'bout this, how about if I made a game where there's just this one cliff you have to jump over and it's like nearly impossible, but if you do it, you win the game and that's it. I mean, what the hell were they thinkin' with this piece of shit? What the hell? Now, if you're a serious Nintendo collector, do yourself a favor, don't get this game, because it's not worth it. I mean, it's made many lives miserable and, y'know, if you see it on sale for a dollar, just stay away. Don't even touch it.

(spits on cartridge and flushes it down the toilet.)

143666212.review:
A charming and devilishly simple but challenging puzzle platformer by Terry Cavanagh (Dicey Dungeons, Super Hexagon). 

You can move left and right but instead of jumping you flip gravity, a simple mechanic but explored in a variety of interesting ways to its fullest extent across the different areas of the game. The puzzles begin simple and grow increasingly complex as you have to deal with auto-scrolling, looping, and even making journeys across multiple screens and back again. There's a surprising amount of variety and challenge that comes from such a simple singular mechanic.

The art may be simplified and the story just an excuse to stitch the puzzles together, but the music is absolutely the highlight here next to gameplay. Every song by Magnus Palsson is a chiptune classic that makes spending time in each area a head bopping pleasure.

While not very long VVVVVV is more minimalist than minimal. It makes the most of what it has to offer and doesn't pretend to be anything more. It doesn't convolute it's design with unnecessary systems, it has some collectables for challenges, explores its one mechanic in interesting ways, and doesn't outstay it's welcome. For the crazy low price now it's a steal and a guaranteed fun 2 hours of gameplay for those who like platformers.

142443561.review:
Shifting gravity is not an uncommon idea in platformers nowadays, but I have never seen it explored as thoroughly as in VVVVVV. Every screen builds on and twists the mechanics with such genius and unpredictability that it's impossible to get bored. The difficulty is high, but made manageable by abundant checkpoints and the platforming being centered around creativity instead of precision. My only nitpick is that there were a few times I was lured into activating a checkpoint that was placed after a trinket, with no easy way to backtrack. This meant I would have to return later and redo some of the platforming to collect it. I don't agree that the game is too short. There's no filler and plenty of replay value with the trinket collecting, time trials, secret achievements, flip and no death modes, and level editor.

When indie platformers are brought up, Shovel Knight and Celeste receive the most attention. VVVVVV should be part of that discussion. It's a perfect example of how focusing on one mechanic can still surprise players in unexpected ways. I'm shocked indie devs don't do this more often since designing several dozen unique mechanics is not only very demanding, but it also invites comparisons to platformers that often do it better, like Mario 3 and Yoshi's Island.

Pros: VVVVVV is quite a difficult platformer with fun mechanics that are taught well.

Neutral: The game has optional trinkets that reward exploration or completing a difficult challenge. However, 2 trinkets are much harder than the rest and there is no achievement for collecting all of the trinkets.

Cons: A few of the achievements require multiple playthroughs of the game. Even though the game is only a few hours long, everything besides the gameplay is only ok, so I don't think going for multiple playthroughs is worth it.

After doing a second playthrough of the game with a bunch of randomized elements the game was more fun than I thought it was. I was too harsh in my original review. Out of the two super hard trinkets one of them is quite manageable on a repeat playthrough and the difficult time and death achievements seem actually doable.

If there's any game I can point to and go "Your grandmother might be able to play it and say she's played a video game more complicated than pong", VVVVVV might be that game. It's incredibly simple. Ya move left and right, and instead of jumping you flip gravity to run on the ceiling. Or the floor...wait, was the floor the ceiling or is the ceiling now the floor...oooghh...

Long story short for a game as short and simple as VVVVVV, get it. It's 5 bucks normally and goes on sale a majority of the time as long as there's a sale available. It's one of the best 2D platformers ever made, and considering it's able to be beaten in an hour, that should say how fantastic the experience is.

VVVVVV es uno de esos juegos inmortales, imperecederos, por los que no pasa el tiempo. Y buena prueba de ello es que 2023 ha sido el año en el que me lo he terminado por primera vez. Sin gafas nostálgicas de por medio. Sin recuerdos de la época dorada del indie nublándome la memoria. 13 años después de su lanzamiento, sin ningún tipo de mochila a la espalda, he instalado la obra maestra de Terry Cavanagh y la he disfrutado tal como imagino que la disfrutó mucha gente en su día: con una perenne sonrisa de tonto pegada en la cara.

Si estás leyendo esto y aún no has jugado a VVVVVV, deja de leerme de una puñetera vez, instálatelo —porque seguro que lo tienes en tu cuenta— y disfruta de uno de los videojuegos más puros, que mejor representan este arte que tanto quiero, porque el bueno de Terry lleva más de un lustro sabiendo perfectamente lo que se hace.

131027464.review: This is by far one of the best indie games I've ever played. I've played through the game multiple times on multiple platforms clearing the map and getting mostly everything in the game. Here I am yet again playing through it, and it's still as good as ever. The graphics are beautiful yet simplistic--there's no need for realism when a few pixels and colors does the job incredibly well. The chiptune soundtrack is perfect; I could listen to it for days and not get tired of it. The controls are great; being able to control Viridian with very little sliding and also freely midair is a wonderful feel. The difficulty is very well handled--nothing too hard nor too easy, and it gives you the option to play in a no death mode as well as challenges. I didn't even know there was a level editor until now since this is the first time I'm playing through Steam. I did, however, play user-made levels in the past since some came preinstalled. Everything was amazing. 11/10 would definitely play through again

125851402.review:
This is 12 years old? You've got to be joking.

I believe that this game excels in almost every aspect.
The music in this is well constructed, and worth listening to outside of the game if it's your type. They generally will match the overall aesthetic and vibe of the area you are playing in.
The graphics are nice, and for 8 pixel by 8 pixel textures, they are pulled off quite well.
There is a free to use, powerful level editor built right into the game, with scripting capabilities along with full size game potential within it. There are external editors too, which if you're interested you can research yourself.
As far as I know, this was the first flip-gravity-instead-of-jumping platformer game, which is a unique mechanic for a platformer.
Individual mechanics are introduced and the difficulty gradually goes up, and provide a decent challenge without overwhelming you.
Collectibles are mostly placed in good locations, however some are exponentially harder or easier to obtain than others.

There are a few levels that are not as good as others, but the final level is a huge issue. It is considerably harder than all the levels previously and doesn't put a good ending impression on any player. It also doesn't build too much on the story because it reuses elements that were already used in story building.

Overall, it's very fun to play through the first time, and is also very replayable with flip mode, or just going for a lower death count or a speedrun. It's also pretty easy to get into level building, and playing other people's levels (though I would not recommend the in-game editor for this.)

My final verdict is an 8.5/10 [Very good]

[b] Time to beat -> 2.3 hours [/b]

Went into this not 100% knowing it was essentially a "you better have patience, or you'll get upset" and I got upset. Doctor, why. Why do you forsake me by walking off the ledge every time...

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 

VVVVVV is your typical press the button at the right time, or you go back to the checkpoint. Fortunately, controls are responsive, there is no input lag, and as far as the challenge goes, at no point did I feel it was overly challenging (I did not get all tokens; apparently there's a super challenging token to grab, not my cup of tea). Completing the "main" story of the game should be within everyone's grasp, even if you have to die 300+ times like me. 

[h1] Things to look out for [/h1]

The spikes...

But seriously, there are a few worries about flashing images in certain game sections. I coin the most prominent offender "The Epilepsy Elephant", to which a giant flashing elephant is in a room without warning. While I don't suffer from Epilepsy, even my eyes were burning at this. Similarly, many rooms could give you a headache if you have trouble handling continuously spinning objects or rooms moving independently to the background.  

[h1] Should you buy? [/h1]

Definitely worth the purchase for a few hours of "I hate myself for buying this game". I had fun streaming this game, and I think, while subjective, that playing this with an audience is a fun time for everyone. If you hate yourself, it has some extra difficulty with the tokens.

10/10 would develop a hatred for doctors again.

Hold on to your tacos! VVVVVV is the best RPG I have played. The characters are so compelling and so life like that it puts Ubisoft to shame. 

You play as Captain and he travels through dimensions to save his lost crew and other dimensions. The captain and his crew must have been motion captured into the game since the movements are so lifelike. At first the story seems slow, but it is all just to set up this amazing discovery of who the Captain really is, who is crew is and why this dimension is really collapsing. Even the title, VVVVVV really gets you going that even before you purchased this game the game devs were already dropping hints for you as the player to suspect what this game is really about.

\\\\\\\\Spoiler Alert////////

Now, for those of you who played the game and actually paid attention to the subtleties of the story line, I want to give you elite a philosophical nugget to chew on. I would like to propose that each dimensional area that The Captain visits, no each screen pan, is a reflection of the Captain's heart while he is on the hunt for each of his crew members. So not only do the dimensions reflect the inevitable doom of our universe, but it also reflects the sometimes more subtle brokenness of our hearts. For this reason, when the crew are all back together again on the Captain's ship, where the rooms make sense, it reflects a wholeness in community which is what I think the secret ending meant. Tell me your thoughts in the comments down below, my philosophy on RPG character arcs is a bit heavy, but I am all ears for discussion on such compelling source material.

122948294.review:
If your idea of a good time involves conquering ridiculous challenges, VVVVVV is absolutely the game for you.

This deceptively fiendish platformer revolves around one simple twist: your character reverses their gravity instead of jumping. As the captain of a space crew caught in interdimensional chaos, you journey through an unknown dimension to rescue your missing crew members. Along the way, you face increasingly difficult puzzles that challenge your creativity and timing. Its world is vast and sadistically challenging, but frequent checkpoints mean you never lose too much progress if you die.

This game is lovingly crafted to maximize player frustration, but the joy in finally beating its difficult levels is indescribably satisfying. This game is absolutely worth it for those who love to experience a little bit of masochism in their gaming.

122544741.review: Let me just start this off by saying that I HATE platformers with a burning passion. I've played everything from Super Mario to Shovel Knight, and nothing makes me more infuriated than the cheesy deaths that are so easy to rage at. This game was no exception. It was frustrating, it was difficult, it was a total pain. But it was also fun. The mechanics are super well rounded and fun, the exploration is super engaging, and the soundtrack is a total bop. They even got Bennett Foddy (Getting Over it) to name the rooms, which ended up having super creative and funny names. Is this game a pain? Yes. It's a platformer, it's in its nature. Every death is more irritating than the last, and it feels like you'll never make it past the room; but you do. While I could never imagine 100%ing this game, I finished the full campaign and really enjoyed myself. I highly recommend this game to anyone, whether you like platformers or not, because if I liked it, you certainly will too.

VVVVVV is a puzzle/platformer with a single mechanic: flipping gravity. even though the focus is clearly on level design, there is somewhat of a story here to follow as well as you play and die many times. the game isn't very long, but mastering it and re-playing the game to try and die as little as possible is very fun as well. you can easily go from dying 1000 times in your first playthrough, to 100 on your second, down to close to 10 on your third, etc. and finally doing a run where you beat the game without dying is very rewarding. there are also time trials to re-play and extra modes to play. this is one of my new favorite 2D platformers of all time, up there with classic games like super mario bros/super mario world.

118491505.review:
I own this game on multiple platforms, including PC, and have beaten it multiple times.

Nevertheless, I bought it for PC again on Steam and have beaten it again, just because this game is so good. 

It will only last you a few hours (less than 2 if you've beaten it multiple times and know where everything is), but it feels much more substantial than the hours you put into it. It's extremely fulfilling and fast paced, with no fluff at all, fast restarts, and frequent checkpoints. Even the hardest parts of the game probably won't take too much of your time, compared to other games with common flaws such as slow death animations and respawns, infrequent checkpoints, and just generally taking way too much time to do things that this game does well. There is also a breadth of postgame content and challenges, including a level editor with the option to import even MORE levels.

Finally, after years of being a complete experience, the game was recently updated with bugfixes and improvements, including an increase from 30fps to whatever-the-heck-you-want fps, and a whole frame of input lag sheered away. This is due to the game's code being made open souce and multiple community members contributing to it, refining the original spaghetti code into the best version of the game, outshining the excellent 60fps console ports. It also includes the options to play the game with the original bugs unfixed, at 30fps, or with the extra frame of input lag, if you really want to play with any or all of those things.

And of course, the base game has always, and will always be, outstanding. An amazing achievement in game design, with charming graphics and one of the best soundtracks of any video game I've ever heard. There is no reason to deprive yourself of this experience for any longer than you need to. Play this game. It is, at the most $5 on Steam. $5 you could spent on an unfulfilling coffee beverage at Starbucks, or an unforgettable video game experience. Choose wisely.

118159945.review:
Originally played and beat this game on 3DS, but decided to get it on Steam for the achievements. What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's hard as heck but also addictive as heck. The game is essentially a pixel Metroidvania, complete with retro music, where the goal is to find the missing members of your spaceship after it crashes. Instead of attacking/jumping like in a traditional platformer, you get around by utilizing a unique gravity shifting mechanic. With this feature, the experience constantly feels challenging yet fresh and exciting - there will be moments where you have to shift over disappearing platforms, avoid spikes or dodge obstacles. At times, there will be bouts of trial and error that will frustrate you, but that quickly disappears once you learn what you're supposed to do (it also has a bit of a puzzle element in a way).

Overall though, I thoroughly enjoyed this game and recommend it to anyone who enjoys challenging games.

117128533.review:
This game had a rough reception (in 2010) but deserves a medal for being crisp, rewarding and cohesive as a neon-wasteland adventure from years before anyone heard of synthwave. It's not terribly long but provides a good challenge. A truly classic platformer that refuses to forgive any mistakes, often requiring you to remember the next three, four or five chambers in both directions just in order to survive.

But after flipping gravity a few dozen times, dodging all the escaped Space Invader pilots and still not learning to hit the checkpoint before yeeting yourself into the abyss, you rescue your first crewman. What follows next is nothing short of a celebration, the pitiful face you find them sporting clears up as soon as they see their beloved captain, assured that survival is imminent. The sheer level of excitement emanating from that little pixelated smile shouldn't be possible, but there it is, making the whole ordeal worth repeating. Hop in the teleporter - thunder cracks - and you're whisked back to the ships bridge to start your next search.

I have to say, I wasn't expecting THAT MUCH from this game, I mean, I had known it was a very good and interesting title, but didn't expect it to be that great. It surpassed my expectations majestically.

This game is start to end a blast to play. You can be beating challenges or just exploring the scenario, it's sooo fun. The flip mechanic is very fun to play with. The OST is amazing. Every track has great quality, they are catchy and hit home. The graphics are simple but lively and colorful. VVVVVV is not that long of a game as it can be cleared in less than 4 hours and that means it will not get tedious overtime, and adding to that, the difficulty is always increasing. Take my word, this game HAS challenge. A few rooms WILL cost you to clear, but overall the game has a fair balance of difficulty. It's not easy, nor unreasonably difficult. The final sections are a true challenge, be prepared to die a lot. The plot is not complex, but it's pretty nice. And also, lore about the dimension where the game happens can be found by reading terminals around. This game has replay value, the scenario is open and well sized for the folks who enjoy exploring, and 20 trinkets scattered around for the folks who enjoy collecting itens and collectibles, and the game is challenging for the folks who enjoy challenge. There are even different gamemodes (which I haven't tried myself so I can't really tell what they are) and an option to toggle a timer (great for speedrunners).

Worth every cent.
10/10

A bit out but kind of a personal take: why did I get attached to the characters? Maybe their bond as crew feels heartwarming for me. I wonder why.

114370124.review:
Absolute must play for platformer enthusiasts. The soundtrack is a banger and every level can be consistently done with enough practice. The game is very replayable too, with there being some freedom of choice in the order you choose to do the stages. Nothing in this game feels completely unfair or out of your control. VVVVVV playthoughs can last between 13 minutes to many hours based on your skill level or if you are going for all 20 collectibles.

However, unlike other platformers, VVVVVV is more trial and error focused as it is nearly impossible to sightread a stage you've been in for the first time. The difficulty is comparable to similar hardcore-platformers as well, as touching any obstacle results in instant death. As a result, this will require you to remember many areas of the game and learn various strategies in order to do them consistently. Memorization is very crucial if you are going for the time trial achievements or the games hardest difficulty, No-Death mode. 

In my and many other's experiences, 1 particular minigame known as "The Gravitron" sticks out among everything. It is required to play an easier version of this minigame for 60 seconds in the main game and No-Death mode. The problem with it is that the obstacles are partially randomized, which could lead to many cheap deaths, especially in No-Death mode or if you are going for the 1 minute challenge on the much harder version of The Gravitron. On the bright side, this game includes speedrun friendly features, such as an old glitches toggle or an in-game timer. Additionally, there is a built in level-editor and some community made levels come preinstalled. Overall, if you are into the hardcore-platformer or the metroidvania genres, you should definitely check out this game.

113137131.review:
Yep, it's a banger. For about a sandwich in monetary terms, this game is a complete steal.

Terry Cavanagh has once again outdone himself with this title, and after both playing, collecting, and speedrunning this game, it's become clear to me that this is not just a classic, but an all-time great.

Here's a couple of things to note before you go and click the little green "Add to Cart" button: [list]
[*]This game is tough. It isn't exactly "slam my desk in rage" tough (except for ONE BIT which I will GET TO LATER), but it has an above-average level of difficulty. 
[*]Yes, I know everyone already knows, but I still need to say it; The soundtrack is a 10/10, and even if you don't buy the game, at least treat your ears to the music. 
[*]Unless you're really going to sink your teeth into this game, expect a few hours of playtime at most. There's a ton of post-game content, and collectibles scattered across the map to boot, but I understand some people just want to see the credits roll.
[/list]
Speaking of collectibles...
The trinket hidden in the room, "Doing Things the Hard Way" (thanks for the room names Bennett) is one of the most devilish sections in videogame history. I'll let you figure out why. However, that's not why I'm annoyed.
The problem is when the game asks you to collect that trinket as fast as you can without dying. There's a reason the "Space Station 2 Mastered" achievement has a 0.9% next to it. Same goes for The Lab, but I'd call the "Pure Unobtanium" trinket slightly easier.

Now, after you've done all you want to in this game, what's next?
Consider speedrunning. Here's my elevator pitch:
We've got plenty of categories, tight competition in IL runs, a couple of really neat glitches, and finally getting the better of this game is super duper fun. Personally, I've got a 16 minute glitchless run and a 14 minute Any% No Text Storage run. Plus our community is very nice.

Please, if you haven't played this game yet, or are just passing by and think it looks neat, BUY THIS. I can't recommend this enough.

112776671.review:
Every few years I'll restart this one and get back into it, and each time I do I am very happy I did.  It's a relatively short jaunt guaranteed to frustrate and then delight you.  

The music is catchy and extremely hum-able which helps those difficult parts when you just keep on dying.  

The controls are sharp and responsive - there is a little bit of momentum in the air but you'll quickly adjust and find yourself skating around spiked corners in no time.   

The difficulty curve is very manageable, but it does get quite difficult as you advance, peaking at the infamous 'Veni Vidi Vici' sequence.  That is a tough spot but there is no better feeling when you land on the right side - and no worse feeling than when you land on the left.  Keep at it, you'll get it!  

You can also find collections of user-made levels online using the in-game level editor tool.  I haven't used this but have played a number of custom levels and love the replayability this gives the game.

I randomly clicked on this one in my library and saw an update - after almost 10 years!  Glad to see there's still some interest, and I installed and beat it once again.  Can't recommend this one enough.

111618013.review:
Honestly, I could never remember if it’s 6 Vs or 7. There were plenty of other things I forgot about this little platforming gem in the decade since I last played it, but the name is definitely the hardest part to stick. I can’t overstate how glad I am I revisited it, though, because VVVVVV is one of the best balances of challenge and chill you can get from indie platformers. It can confound and mystify without frustrating, and always offers you something new to do if you’ve come across a particularly tricky section. And even if you do find yourself starting to fume, the thick layer of charm laid on by the adorable characters and retro stylings is sure to put you back in your comfort zone.

It’s a disaster…IN SPAAAAAACE! Captain Viridian’s ship has crashed in an unknown sector of the universe, and his crew has been scattered by a mysterious disruption. It’s up to him to reunite the team and figure out what the heck happened to the ship, and fortunately, he’s the perfect person to do it. Not only does he have a winning smile and a can-do attitude, he can also flip his personal gravity at will. That’ll prove invaluable when facing the twisting corridors and yawning voids of this enigmatic place. Each new challenge will push him in different and unexpected ways, and ultimately lead to some big revelations about where his ship ended up, and where it’s going.

VVVVVV has a perfectly serviceable story for the kind of game it is, a framework to hang fantastical platforming and exploration upon. There are terminals dotted about that give a little more context to the story beats that happen from time to time, but again, plumbing the depths of this strange space is the real attraction here. The map is wide open, with a vast Super Metroid-esque landscape sprawling in all directions just outside your ship. From here, tunnels and passageways lead to more discrete sections that present thematic challenges like moving platforms, edge-wrapping mazes, and a particularly harrowing tower ascent. Your crew tends to be tucked away at the ass-ends of each of these areas, and each adds their own little colorful observations about the predicament you find yourself in.

The platforming is the real star of the show here, because it takes a wonderfully Bionic Commando approach to powerful yet limited mobility. All you can do is run left, run right, or reverse your own gravity while on solid ground. With no discrete ability to jump, a single-tile obstruction can be a greater obstacle than a yawning laser-filled chasm if there’s no clear way to gravity-flip over it. And trust me, the game makes incredible use of this dynamic in all of its areas. Platforming takes on a whole new dimension here, with ceilings becoming just as important as floors and nominally simple jumps turning into an entire process when you can only flip around the extremes of the problem. Some of the challenges are infamous, such as a multi-screen ascent and descent through a spiked gauntlet just to clear a tiny ankle-high wall.

Most importantly, though, is that nothing here is particularly stressful. Aided by the simple, charming art style, VVVVVV is ultimately a very inviting game, even when facing you with a twisting passage of death. Checkpoints are dotted practically every other screen, and retries are instantaneous, meaning you can fling yourself to your doom as much as you want and waste very little time doing it. The hardest challenges are also reserved for the optional collectibles scattered across the world, and even then don’t reach the same heights as some modern metroidvanias in difficulty. A wealth of fast-travel teleporters on top of all this makes it clear that this game can be taken at your pace, as far as you want, as long as you’re having fun with it.

That was the biggest feeling that flooded back to me when I replayed VVVVVV recently, just how outright fun the whole thing is. I never got stuck anywhere, never raged at any of the challenges, and always had a huge smile on my face when I rescued one of my wayward crewmates. I don’t want to hear any complaints about the pixel art, because the clean lines and stark colors really help emphasize the platforming. The sound design is a perfect match to the retro feel, with big boops and beeps that I love (and I cannot lie). VVVVVV is regarded as a classic for good reason, offering timeless challenge and exploration without ever really pushing you out of that cozy, comfortable space.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

It feels like driving a race car with slick tires on drenched dirt. The acceleration and deceleration greatly assists you to slide right into a spike trap after landing on a tiny platform, and gives almost authentic early 90s feeling. It is especially useful at that when you might be able to actually land correctly after jumping off a conveyor belt.

Even the core game itself (bonuses and challenges excluded) gets very challenging at times, and getting all 20 trinkets is very hard. it is basically choreography, you memorize the moves and then execute it. Luckily for me, someone else have done that with AutoHotkey for Doing Things The Hard Way. That said, even the tool had some difficulties executing it precisely enough, it was not consistent enough, but I got it after several attempts.

I would still rate the game mostly positively. The story is nice, albeit its text is as minimalistic as its graphics. Generally I would say the design is nice. But with reviews so overwhelmingly positive, I think negative reviews are lacking.

If you had a good day, you feel great, and all you want is something challenging to get you focused, stressed, and perhaps even frustrated, before you finish it and become happy again, feel free to try. If you had a bad day or you are on a sick leave and you already feel like s**t, stay away from this game, it will mostly just make your day worse.

107331423.review:
I reviewed this game before with an also negative review, but now that I've actually uh...beaten it, I feel like I should rewrite my review. This game is still pretty bad. 

If I had to describe VVVVVV in one statement, I'd say "precision platformer on an ice level". The controls really are the main challenge of the game, and it feels very artificial. Captain Viridian controls like he's made of wet soap, usually taking what feels like (and might even be) half a second to come to a complete stop. You'd think the level designs would account for this, but no; the levels all feel like they were designed with a character with tight controls in mind. That's not even mentioning the fact that things like spikes have hitboxes that seem to actually be bigger than the sprite itself; I've had many instances of death where Viridian is obviously not contacting the spike, but dies anyway. Combine this with the terrible controls, and you get deaths that realistically aren't your fault. YOU didn't input that extra movement, YOU didn't hit the obstacle, and as such, YOU should not have died. But, of course, you do anyway. 

What sucks more is if the controls were tighter, this would definitely be a positive review, since that's realistically the only problem with the game. Sure some trinkets have really bad placement (Veni, Vidi, Vici is unreasonably hard given the controls, and there are multiple sections that kill you almost immediately upon respawn, which is not good), but by and large the level design is excellent, and would provide a fun (if really big) challenge. That's not even mentioning the fact that the music and graphics are both unmistakably great, especially given it was one of the earlier pixel-indie-game types. The music I especially want to draw attention to (Positive Force goes so hard). The story is simple, but does what you'd expect well.

Finally, and this is especially important to me personally, the game has no cloud saves. There never has been and never will be an excuse to cheap out and not include cloud saves, especially when your game is STILL UPDATED. If you pay money for a game on Steam, it should have cloud saves, regardless of what the game is or how much it costs. They're not a hard feature to implement, and they save SO much hassle for transferring saves between machines. Cloud saves can be added to games post-release too, so that's not an excuse either. 

TL;DR, game has slippery controls and no cloud saves, and sadly, despite its great artwork and music, I think those flaws are enough to justify a negative review. I don't see myself returning once I get all the trinkets.

The main objectives of the game are to rescue the 6 crew members all who have gotten lost behind a series of platforming challenges and let me say this game has some pretty hard ones in it. I spent upwards of 40 minutes trying to get a certain trinket in this game (this game's collectibles) and it was driving me crazy. I honestly don't recommend going for all the trinkets if you're playing this game for the first time, just go for the shipmates and you'll have more fun with it, just chill out to the awesome soundtrack and the normal campaign is a breeze.

It's a quintissential indie game, it's definitely a modern classic in my eyes and I recommend it if you're looking for a challenge.

[h1]At-A-Glance:[/h1]
[b]Game type:[/b] Action
[b]Genre(s):[/b] Puzzle platformer, Sci-fi
[b]Art:[/b] 4-bit retro pixel art
[b]Length:[/b] Short (2-5 hours)
[b]Pace:[/b] Fast-paced
[b]Tags:[/b] Retro, Commodore 64-style, amazing soundtrack, optimized play
[b]Computer requirements:[/b] Very low-end


[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[olist]
[*] [i]VVVVVV[/i] was one of the first games of its time to typify the kind of hardcore, difficult platformer challenge alongside [i]I Wanna Be the Guy[/i] and of course [i]Super Meat Boy[/i]. I can't believe this game is already 11 years old - and I also can't believe it's only 11 years old given it feels like such a part of the indie game zeitgeist.
[*] Super, super fast-paced platforming with immediate restarts that gives you the same kind of hyperfocus like [i]Hotline Miami[/i] - though a little bit different in subject matter.
[*] Awesome soundtrack that's up there with [i]Shovel Knight[/i] in appropriateness, catchiness, and listening appeal. This is absolutely a game where you want to get the soundtrack - you [i]will[/i] want to listen to it outside of the game.
[*] I love these little astronauts. They're so dang cute.
[*] Though short, there's plenty of challenge to be had here - especially in the challenge modes!
[*] This will run on literally anything. The minimum specs are for Windows XP! And, I have absolutely no problem running it on a much, much more modern system.
[/olist]

105231449.review:
To put it charitably - the game didn't age well.

It's a precision platformer that has character inertia, vsync on as default and no support for exclusive fullscreen, [spoiler]so have fun with that pesky input lag, enforced by Microsoft's trademark DWM[/spoiler]
You do the math.

* * *
[ts;wm]
The metroidvania aspect of exploring the grey areas of the map is a nice addition, but the game's sole gimmick of gravity flipping, replacing the jump button, (combined with the drab art style) doesn't last long, before slowing the pace down to a dull slog of looking for mcguffin collectibles and trying to overcome the temptation to uninstall the game after your NPC partner fails to do precisely as you say for the fifteenth time.

As I said - it didn't stand the test of time (or of anything else).
This game simply wouldn't survive its release in a post-greenlight era, where on one hand you have hundreds and thousands of lazy asset store flips that look ten times more appealing than this game and on the other you have genuine masterpieces that do the same, do it better and sometimes even for free (for an example, look up Down Ward... the one with the owl; or the critically panned / overlooked "Marvin the Hatter")

* * *

I'm frankly stunned with the both "Very Positive" and, even more so, all-time "Overwhelmingly Positive" rating, which it definitely does not deserve.

Pros 
- Very nice aesthetic, really brings it back to old school gaming
- The MUSIC!  Absolute bops all around the area when you're exploring
- Simple to learn gameplay that gets challenging through a playthrough
- Runs on about anything, not a super intensive game to play
- Very replayable due to its pick-up and play style where you can just jump in at anytime after a break without being lost.

Cons
- Dying in the game can get slightly cumbersome as it's not as 100% snappy compared to other challenge-based platformers, and the checkpoint system can be unforgiving at times.
- The game is quite short to just play through (around 2 hours for finishing the story), but for the price (and if you get it on sale), it's worth it.
- The game outside of the specific level zones is a bit too open, so you can fly across a lot of the map (due to the gimmick of the game) when you don't want to, so traversing the world can be difficult.

Absolutely try it out, it's a fun time all around!

102429436.review:
Played this a ton on 3DS growing up and practically memorized all of it. This is the idyllic example of a very short game with very high replay value. It's comforting for me to just sit down and play through it all over again in about half an hour or so, at this point I'm probably really disconnected from the experience of the original playthrough.

There isn't a single part of the game that drags or feels obnoxious to go through again to me aside from a couple of the optional trinkets. Every stage in this game is super creative and it has a banger soundtrack. Most of the time it's a lot less about having extreme precision and more about executing the trick/strategy to the puzzle the level is presenting to you correctly, and figuring out that strategy in the first place. Each stage has a new mechanic that it throws at you to keep your on your toes, but none of them wear out their welcome. You might get tilted your first couple of playthroughs or when trying to go for optional content, but it's well worth it. There's no excuse to not have this game in 2021.

After the base game, tons of additional challenge await those who are not yet satisfied, such as complete the game in no death mode. Totally recommend it.

102303243.review:
This is one of those games that everyone seems to love except for me. In my opinion, much of what makes a great platformer great is how it feels to play - the physics of the game/character and the control you have over your character. This game just didn't do it for me in terms of "feel." The movement is jerky, and that is very frustrating in a game that demands precision. In addition to the abrupt movements of the character, there are a lot of blind jumps and falls that will kill you because it's difficult to react to them in time. This game isn't nearly as soul-crushingly difficult as people make it out to be; I didn't really have any issue with the puzzles themselves aside from the aforementioned blindness. I think the puzzles were thoughtfully designed for the most part, and a handful of them were quite clever. My frustrations came completely from the lack of control. 

I won't go into too much detail, but the overworld (or whatever you want to call it) is maybe the worst overworld I've seen. Not really sure what they were thinking there.

All that said, the characters are cute, the art suits the gameplay, and the music really stands out. Unfortunately, the gameplay itself kept me from really enjoying it all.

102128952.review:
First of all, I personally pronounce VVVVVV as /vi vi vi vi vi vi/ (that's written in the International Phonetic Alphabet). Others say "V times six" or "V six times".

Ok, with that out of the way: In my opinion, this game is:

- An instant platformer indie classic of the same high caliber as Shovel Knight

- And a must buy for every platformer fan

I can't believe I had this game sitting in my library, collecting digital dust, for so long! However, in a way that was a good thing because I got to play it with the August 2021 update. Yup, the game got a (most likely final) update a decade after it was originally released!

VVVVVV was a charming and pretty fun, although somewhat short, platforming experience for me. The main gimmick of this game is that instead of jumping you reverse gravity, and you use that mechanic to traverse and maneuver through the different levels and sections in the game's world / dimension while trying to avoid different kinds of obstacles.

You will face some easy challenges, some moderate challenges, and a few really hard challenges which will require you to arm yourself with patience! The "Doing Things the Hard Way" gauntlet to get one of the collectible trinkets is pretty difficult, but with a lot of practice [b]and mountains of patience[/b], I'm pretty sure you'll be able to eventually complete it.

I enjoyed the game's simple but colorful pixel graphics, I liked the few character interactions here and there, and the music is great! I have no complaints about the controls, except for the fact that Captain Viridian (your playable character) has a bit of momentum when moving, which led to many unintentional deaths... but I guess a bit of momentum is part of the challenge.

VVVVVV also has a number of modes to play and mess around with once you complete the main game, such as Time Trials, Flip Mode, and one fun but pretty hard mini-game you can get if you obtain all the trinkets.

Oh, and I also liked how you have to explore the world / dimension in order to find each new level. That was enjoyable, and added a small "metroidvaniay" touch to the game, so to speak.

In conclusion: If you like platformers, I definitely recommend VVVVVV, even at full price (although it tends to go for 75% off during most sales). And if you aren't into platformers yet, I would still encourage you to at least give this game a try.

100915977.review:
PROS:
-Delightfully simple
-Impeccable soundtrack
-Fun story with a delightful atmosphere
-Lots of personality plus a great sense of humor
-Unnamed levels are really cool exploration pieces
-Really satisfying to find all the locations on the map
-The Tower and Final Challenge are awesome vertical sequences
-Escort mission is such an excellent idea
-Game is great at challenging you in the final sections by making you use what you've learned in isolation together and in harder sections
-Ton of cool mechanics that build on the idea of flipping and the basic gameplay mechanics
-Reward for getting all trinkets is really cool and cute
-Offers further challenge in the form of time trials
-Custom level support + built in level editor
-JUST RECENTLY got an update where as a direct result of the source code being available, the game received a ton of QoL stuff (despite it being an 11 year old singleplayer game)

CONS:
-Veni Vidi Vici (one of the hardest optional sequences in the game) is too easy to get to despite being super early in the game
-Some checkpoints level design causes you to accidentally hit other checkpoints or go to other areas due to stuff like conveyors or just positioning (cuckoo x backsliders)
-Brass Sent Us in Under the Top is really stupid for forcing you to stay off screen but the cycle keeps going offscreen, so you have to estimate how far along it is
-Too much visual noise in the flip lines area; rectangles in background need to be more transparent
-Trinkets (optional collectibles) don't have names that are puns on the areas you find them in for organization's sake and also for cool puns

I played this game all the way through once before on a 3DS on a road trip from Texas to Tennessee, and it was an absolute blast. Decided to pick it up again recently just for the sake of having it on Steam. Got all 20 trinkets and explored the map in its entirety. There's a bunch of optional challenges you could do, but I was satisfied with the campaign + trinkets.

Short, but well worth the money. A must-have for any platformer fan, or just a fan of games. Pick it up when you can!

100910489.review:
VVVVVV is a VVVVVVideo gaeM.

uhhhhh

And it's pronounced as exxxtra thicc long VVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVVV. Er, V.

A "hard" type precision platformer. With Commodore 64 style graphics, or other old computers. Which is cute, it has a bit of that feel, with absolute banger of a soundtrack, and a bit of abstract nonsense of some famed computer platformers with random symbols as enemies that just follow path pattern and random names for each room which can be very cute. Quirky stuff, a mainstay of indies, albeit that elephant was mighty weird in a cool way.

...oh, it's a game where your your main physics action of platformer, that is usually a jump, is replaced with flipping gravity. You can do it only when on the ground, so no, you can't just flip endlessly in air and be like a ghost cheatah. This power is not explained through in-game narrative, no, don't think so.
Man, I can't believe I almost forgot to mention the main feature of the game, how can I even function and write reviews when I don't force myself to take notes. Answer: barely.

It's a cute game but compared to other first wave indie games of 2010, all the classics, this one just doesn't really hit the string in any special way or memoriable way. It's short and feels simple and well just just just.

Furthermore, it's kinda not very good at the genre is challenges. Precision hard platformer? Cool, but why in the world is main hero so slippery on the stop then? That has given me too many deaths and haven't led satisfaction on beating hard platformer challenge, not as much. And on top... Escort missions.
Escort missions.
Escort missions.
In imprecise platformer like that. Now you have to escord a twat who is few steps behind and follows same imprecise physics rules.
Thank gosh for infinite tries.

At least you don't need to 100% game, just beat main content which isn't as hard as some trinkets. You need to get all trinkets to unlock secret area but it's not a plot-twisting awesome new ending. Sorta has some narrative but primarly bonus stuff area.

So yes, 6/10. 7/10. Sorta there. 3/5. 4/5. Epic chiptune smiple-ish adventure with interesting asthetics. With historical popularity, but not exactly a classic of gem quality.

P.S. Why does Steam have some shovelware-ish title called VVVVV? Sounds like a scam. Which is depressing cus from screenshot it has nice gameplay and assets but I know well nowadays how much of asset grab there is.

+ Fairly short, but lots to do after completion, such as time trials, completion with fewer deaths etc.

98789324.review:
VVVVVV is a short but memorable precision platformer that asks a deceptively simple question: What if, instead of jumping, the player flipped gravity to progress through the game?

As of writing this review I've...
- beaten this game at least four different times (several of which took place in one sitting)
- gifted it once
- bought the soundtrack (which is really, really good I might add)

The game is just somehow so fun to play. It's hard, even after beating it four times, but checkpoints are all over the place. Thus, while it is hard, it's not terribly punishing (unless you go for the optional collectibles). It's just very satisfying to weave your way through the spikes and other hazards successfully. It's not a very long game (my first playthrough was roughly two hours long) but I personally prefer shorter games like this. With a bit of practice, you can easily beat the game in one sitting. I just played through it again today and got all the optional collectibles in less than an hour.

The music is also amazing. Honestly some of the best chiptune I've ever heard, and I've listened to a lot of chiptune music.

The graphics aren't that great, but to be fair, the game is trying to look like its from the Commodore 64. They serve their purpose, and precision platformers don't really offer time to take in the scenery anyways. The recent update to support framerates above 30 FPS helped make the game look a lot nicer.

My one issue with this game is that the player doesn't move slowly, but this is only an issue if you try to inch your way forward bit by bit. You try for inches but end up getting feet. However, the level design doesn't usually ask you to make small adjustments like this, and if you do get killed by this, you don't get set back very far because the checkpoints are everywhere. This one issue doesn't do much to impact the rest of the game's incredible offerings.

I cannot recommend this game enough. Easily a favorite. The dev has two other games and both are amazing as well.

Classic indie "you have one gimmick" platformer. Not as influential as Braid in the "you have one gimmick" puzzle platformer category, but from around the same time, and a lot of fun to actually play through. The actual game is fairly short at about 2-3 hours depending on how often and how long you get stuck, but if you're into that kind of thing, it has several challenge modes and support for custom levels, so it's got more play value than just the 2-3 hour main game, too.

The soundtrack is also A+, but the controls are slightly too loose for when it asks you to make tight maneuvers. Thankfully, it's the sort of game where restarting after a death is almost instant, but it still feels like I'm just flinging myself in the right direction and hoping most of the time. Still, an easy recommendation for a game I actually thought I played back in 2010 or so. My Steam playtime was zero, though, so I either played a different version or confused myself.

I like VVVVVV. It's elegantly simple, with lots of exploration to be done, and really interesting difficulty spikes. The soundtrack is an absolute joy to listen to, and a massive part of the appeal. 

VVVVVV's extremely barebones. All you have are the abilities to move left and right, as well as swapping gravity. The game takes that mechanic to the absolute limit, with so many different types of obstacles and ideas. It's an incredibly simple game with a very simple and short story. I'd say it'll take you 3-4 hours to complete the story. The collectibles may take longer. Haven't tried the level editor, but I'm sure there are some just lovely levels.

I wouldn't recommend it for everyone though, some people may be annoyed with the metroidvania style exploration. It's a good game, but if you aren't invested early into it, you won't be invested later into it. 

Veni-Vidi-Vici's impossible too. Good luck with that trinket,

95852969.review:
TLDR: A difficult platformer where jumping is replaced with switching gravity. A short but sweet story, a lot of difficulty, and fun.
Warning: If you have epilepsy or bright flashes bother you a lot, don't play this. Bright flashes and changing colours are par for the course.
In more detail: VVVVVV is a really neat puzzle platformer. If you don't go out of your way to get all the little things, then the story can be completed in maybe an hour or two. However, completing the difficult challenges is a big part of the fun. The puzzles are smart but not impossible to figure out, and require you to use your skill with the game. A lot like Portal in how it makes you learn a new set of rules, this time for gravity instead of portals. 
You play as Captain Viridian, the Captain of a starship which has been tossed into chaos, and are charged with rescuing the rest of the crew. Viridian, and indeed the rest of the crew, are represented by little chubby stick figures, and if you're hoping for graphics beyond what you can see in the banner, you'll be sorely disappointed. The art style is very simple. Where VVVVVV shines is in the gameplay; it has several different modes, lots of little challenges, and a decently big map to explore. The story is more of an accessory to the gameplay, but it's enjoyable for what it is.
I'd say that VVVVVV is kind of like a cross between LaserCat and Portal; metroidvania-style map with tons of rooms, 2D, but with an interesting mechanic which makes it engaging and lends itself to new puzzles, and each level introducing a new element to diversify the puzzles.
I don't know if I'll be coming back to VVVVVV since I'm not much of one for time trials or no-death runs, but for those who are, VVVVVV has a good few more hours of gameplay.

94640346.review:
I was enjoying the game when I entered a new area. A sign said “Nobody will get this one”. Just to my side was a shiny trinket, whose acquisition was a bonus objective, not required to beat the game. But I was separated from the trinket by a slight bump. Because you cannot jump in this game, I had to reverse gravity and go up, then down. But up was a maze-shaft of spikes. I knew I had to do it.

I tried dozens of times maneuvering around the spikes. Went through several screens but didn’t reach the top yet. I thought there would at least be a checkpoint on top. There wasn’t. There was a platform that disappeared after you stood for too long.

After reaching the platform I had to come all the way back, the same way I got to the top, avoiding the spikes. As there was no checkpoint, every death I had to repeat the whole journey from the beginning.

Time passed and I was getting better. I began reaching the top pretty consistently. I gradually became better at flying between the spikes. I almost did it a few times.

And then finally. After around half an hour of play, and at least 300 deaths. I did it. I got the trinket.

Throughout these 30 minutes, I didn’t rage a single time. I would’ve raged if I was doing something I needed. But I wasn’t. I was doing something I wanted.

Pretty good game.

Very Fun Game! The retro-esque gravity defying platformer VVVVVV takes one back to the days of better gaming -- where skill actually matters because the reward is worth it. You'll find the game-play difficult but not overly so and the payoff of finding new areas or making an "impossible" maneuver worthwhile. The music gives me goosebumps and fits in quite well with the game -- that of exploring space in an strange and unknown dimension to find your crew-mates. Precision platforming -- retro style -- at its best!

This was one of my first Games in 2013 when I made this account and I still love to look back at it and remember my time in VVVVVV.

94635098.review: A classic indie "platformer" that has held up to the test of time. I quick, fun, and cheap experience worth taking an hour or two to play through.

94629836.review:
This is a relic from the first wave of indie games, and the fond memories people have of this game (myself included) are largely due to the fond memories they have of that time in gaming -- an age where the concept of indy titles that were more than freeware, but less than AAA and artistically unfettered by corporate greed.

The truth is this game sucks. It is charming for sure, maybe even clever in spots, but the bottom line is this is a precision platformer that lacks precision. That is as fatal a flaw as there can be. The way through a level is almost always bog simple, and most you will blow through most of them on the 1st or 2nd try. However, maybe 10 or 15% of the content requires legitamitely precise movement and it is there you realize how bizarre the physics are, how janky and imprecise the movement is (wait for the escort mission! yep an escort mission in a fake Atari 2600 game) and that if you must play a precision platformer from the early days of indy gaming then better to start a new Super Meat Boy campaign than slog through this also-ran.

93516869.review: This game is short but immensely satisfying. The main game can be completed in just a couple of hours, and the full completion of the main game (all collectibles) adds some challenge and a little extra meat to the game. For the truly masochistic, there are a variety of challenges / achievements which are insanely difficult. Completing the game without dying and surviving longer than a minute in the minigame are both brutally hard, but the game is short enough that those who are interested in that kind of thing could sink the time in without the game becoming too unwieldy. 92597770.review:
PROS
>Was released in 2010, so can easily run on ancient computers like mine. The pixelated graphics certainly don't hurt your graphics card either.
>Neat little retro soundtrack that fits the game incredibly well
>Unique from many other platformers out there
>Lots of different game mechanics that keep things fresh
>The frequent checkpoints make it so you don't have to repeat stuff you already did (except, maddeningly, for between Vertigo and The Voon Show. Could really do with one there.) 
>Clever stages and room names
>Fairly priced
>Finished the game? Speedruns are certainly possible, or you could try to explore the entire map, which is surprisingly big! There are also 20 trinkets to collect around the map, so if you are looking to squeeze a bit more life out of the game once you're done, you can try going for those.
CONS
>Although the small size is necessary for the game to be as charming as it is, I'd love to spend more time in it. Unless you're speedrunning or just bad at the game like me, you won't get more than 20 hours from it.
>Very little plot, but that's rather standard for platformers.
>Maybe nitpicky, but once you've finished a level there's pretty much no replay value.

All in all, VVVVVV is great and I would certainly recommend it to anyone! :D

91695062.review:
10/10

VVVVVV was one of the first indie games I ever played, and it was the game that got me to fall in love with the platformer again, a genre that I'd left behind more than 15 years prior when I moved to console RPG's, shortly after which I'd moved to PC gaming.  I actually played through it again a couple months ago, and it still holds up to this review score and to my original perception of the game.  

VVVVVV does not use conventional platformer jumping, instead allowing the player to essentially "flip" gravity - when you jump, you'll keep going up until you land on the ceiling - potentially many screens above you, in some areas.  VVVVVV's mechanics and puzzles are quickly intuitive and understandable and each of the 6 main areas uses a new mechanic to add to the basic mechanics of the game.  VVVVVV is difficult but also generally forgiving, allowing newer or less skilled players to approach the game fairly easily and simply work their way through puzzles through by quickly trying over and over again.  At the same time, it allows for more advanced players to challenge themselves through both the basic "campaign" as well as through the time trials associated with it.  The overall style of the game is excellent, with fantastic music and excellent pixel art, as well as a sense of humor about itself.  If you haven't played a platformer in a long time, VVVVVV is a great way to jump back into the genre without an overly long commitment (the game can be easily completed by a first-timer in 3-4 hours) or without subjecting yourself to overly punishing and difficult mechanics like some competitors.  If you've enjoyed other PC platformers but you haven't played VVVVVV, its mechanics are fun and unique enough to justify a purchase and will give a skilled platformer a worthwhile playthrough.

90945953.review:
[h1] VVVVVV - timeless indie classic[/h1]

[i]One of my all time favourites (if not my absolute favourite, comming from someone having played Half Life, Castlevania SotN, Mario Galaxy, Journey, Portal 2).[/i]

[u]GAMEPLAY:[/u]
The gameplay is [b]simple and effective[/b], it's exactly what it needs to be, nothing more, nothing less. Two buttons for horizontal movement and one button to [b]flip gravity[/b] (and another for using machines). The game's pretty [b]twitchy[/b] though, but there's an [b]option to slow down the game's speed[/b] if that's a problem for you. You can save at big teleporters or at any time in the pause menue. It's a [b]puzzle platformer[/b], you dodge enemies, avoid spikes and solve the challenges presented to you, sometimes requiring you to actively think about how you approach a situation.
The obstacles you face require [b]fast reflexes, dexterity and, above all else, perserverance[/b]. But the game throws [b]checkpoints[/b] at you in almost every room so it is never too hard and [b]always fair[/b]. Should a challenge pose too difficult, you can always go into the options where you can enable an "invincibility cheat".
You can also use a [b]Controller[/b] if you want to. Personally, I [b]prefer the keyboad[/b], as the twitchy nature of the game demands [b]precise and immediate inputs[/b], like having to press left and right in quick succession, which is easier with keyboards.

[u]GAME WORLD:[/u]
The [b]overworld[/b] is a partially non-euclidian [b]maze[/b], that begs you to explore and fill in every tile on the map.
Hidden across the [b]open maze[/b] are mostly [b]linear Zones[/b] that serve as the levels. Each level has a unique theming and expands on a different concept like conveyer belts or lines that switch gravity when touched.
You can tackle them in any order you want.
The [b]pacing[/b] within the linear levels is great. You never grow bored or exhausted. Outside in the open maze it can naturally vary, as an open structure largly depends on the player for its pacing. The [b]overworld is quite easy[/b], expect for some sudden spike pits, and can be a little boring sometimes. It circumvents this with plenty of teleporters used for [b]fast-travel[/b], even though the [b]world is quite small and dense[/b]. Certain patches of tiles/rooms of the map are just empty as well, which gets disorienting and forces you to look at the map. If they were filled with a handful of random debris it would be easier to tell where you are and you wouldn't have to wait for a dozen seconds of free falling until you can flip again.

[u]MUSIC:[/u]
The music is [b]catchy, timeless and nothing short of outstanding[/b]. Souleye managed to create tracks that bring you into a dream like state, soothing most anger, and the pieces range from beautifully melancholic, to just cool and epic, to cheerful, some fast and some slow paced. It feels almost like each track is from a different genre and yet they all fit together seemlessly. If you don't like [b]oldschool pixel game bit sounds[/b], there are power metal versions of the soundtrack made by Souleye  himself online (VVVVVV - MMMMMM) that sometimes put an interesting spin on the original, like Predestined Fate starting with a romantic spanish-ish guitar as the quiet melancholy of low electronic blips doesn't translate well into e-guitar music.

[u]STORY:[/u]
The main story in of itself is [b]really simple[/b]: Rescue your lost crewmates. Though there are some [b]minor twists and turns[/b] that keep things interesting in terms of unexpected occurances, no drama between the characters or character arcs. But to those that want more: there are terminals scattered across the desolate dimension serving as [b]worldbuilding[/b], telling you the [b]backstory[/b] of the strange place you found yourself in, giving you bits and pieces and leaving some room for theories and interpretations.
A shortcomming may be the [b]lack of proper set dressing[/b]. Many areas are said to represent space stations, labs etc. but they all just feel pretty much alike in the sense that everything feels like a videogame level instead of believable places even with a lot of fantasy. But [b]prioritizing level design over visual worldbuilding[/b] is always the right choice for a platformer.

[u]BONUS CONTENT:[/u]
[b]Challenge modes:[/b] Time trials, no death runs, a vertically mirrored playthrough and a survival challenge. [b]20 optional collectibles[/b] with a [b]worthy completion reward[/b]. And after all that you can make your own game with the [b]level editor[/b]! I haven't really played around with it, but from what I've seen from the creations of other players, [b]you could almost rebuild the main game from scratch[/b] if you wanted to, the only things that SEEM to be missing are the option for the escort missions (don't worry they're actually good) and making autoscrollers (also good), you can even make cutscenes!
There are plenty of [b]player created levels[/b] for you to go through. I recommend "333333 easy mode" especially, which serves as a spiritual sequel to the main campaign. Be weary of "Golden Spiral" though, unless you got a punching bag around.

[u]CONCLUSION:[/u]
[b]I VERY STRONGLY recommend this game.[/b] The only potential turn off may be the [b]difficulty[/b] that will proof too much for those new to platformers or videogames in general, but that's what the [b]invincibility option[/b] is for. You also have [b]infinite attempts[/b], no Game Overs.
The main campaign ( = disregarding bonus content) is [b]short and sweet[/b]. You could get to the end within a single day; the longevity comes from the challenge modes and player levels.
It is a [b]puzzle platformer[/b], so you also have to think sometimes to progress, instinctive play won't get you through ALL situations. The only negative I can think of is that the game only shows you one room at a time, which means that when you exit a room the [b]view suddenly snaps to the next room[/b], there's no gradual shift and the game doesn't freeze movement while it shifts, which can potentially be disorienting (the only exception is are a few autoscroller sections, which is way better than it sounds), but I think that may have been intentional and it avoids significant leaps of faith by showing you rooms beforehand that require "correct falling".
There are [b]accessiblity options[/b]: disable animated backgrounds, disable effects like screen flashes, invinciblity (which causes only minor glitches like a random moving platform being stuck, it won't crash or corrupt your game) and adjusting the game's speed.
The vibes from this game have caught me up in a dream time and time again. I am not a mental health professional, but I seriously consider giving this game to someone going through a rough time as the game effortlessly tells a simple tale about positivity and perserverance in a desolate, hostile world without getting obnoxious about it, beating the odds and coming out the other end with a big smile on your face!
You definitly get your money's worth here tenfold! The game is also quite small with 70MB and can be downloaded in one or two breaths using my average Wifi at the end of space and time. Even with a singificantly worse connection I reckon it would hardly even take 10 minutes.

A solid V out of 10 :D !

90097177.review:
Not as elegant as Don't Look Back before it or synthetic as Super Hexagon after, VVVVVV still builds up well enough on a simple premise—just like any other Terry Cavanagh's project. Mechanics are simple enough for it to even afford dropping its single action button for a directional-only control scheme if the player chooses so: in a platformer where jumping is replaced with straight-up/down “flipping” (gravity-wise, that is) buttons can be an extravagance.

The spacetime issues that move the plot forward also permeate the game (on purpose or not) stylistically, lending it a rough-around-the-edges feel: graphics, sound effects and gameplay emulate the Atari 2600 era, while the soundtrack and metroidesque structure is more akin to the following console generation. Also, execution is just as uneven—music transitions sound weird at times, the pseudo-infinite Defender-like outer space areas are too empty and bland for their own good... and spikes shouldn't be allowed to kill from the side after Sonic the Hedgehog.

But when VVVVVV is good (for the most part, that is) it rocks. Level design—when it's due—is brilliant and plays a huge role in rendering the game compelling as it is. Such a tough challenge (almost 8-bit tough) could only be tackled nowadays with some modern, smart use of checkpoints and respawn rates.

A first playthrough may pile hundreds of deaths by the end of an average 2-hour run; but in VVVVVV that not necessarily means discouraging the player while at it.
