88139134.review:
[b]A redundant rearview mirror[/b]  

[u]Reasons to play:[/u] 
[list] 
[*]Challenging platforming
[*]High intensity music
[*]Retro charm
[/list] 
[u]Negatives:[/u] 
[list] 
[*]Excessive trial and error
[*]Unforgiving mechanics
[*]Inconsistent controls
[*]Gimmicky to a fault
[*]Uninspired visuals and plot (which leaks into level design)
[/list]
  
[b]Only recommended for hardcore platformers[/b]


[hr][/hr] 

[h1] Review [/h1]

Despite it's flaws, appreciation for games always comes down to genre preference and the caveat needs to be made before you discard my review, that I am not a vivid gamer per se and like my games with a clear focus on audiovisual design and narrative themes. VVVVVV is at its core a game for gamers. If you like overcoming challenges and achieving a goal with a proneness for difficult progression, I highly recommend VVVVVV, but as it stands this is not the kind of game that I will remember as a holistic experience but simply a simulator for frustration.

You're supposed to die a lot in this game, but I can't see how falling through a screen with no information only to get spiked and redo this again and again makes for fun gameplay. The mechanic of reversing gravity instead of jumping is brilliant for sure (however narratively nonsensical), but the movement controls are unresponsive and slippery while some rooms are so fast paced you more often than not look at yourself in disbelief that you made it through, like Samuel L. Jackson in "the miracle" of Pulp Fiction.

You're told that some environments represent something, like your spaceship hub world, but the retro visuals are at most a neon bright unintelligible mess of passages (and spikes baaad). The music though is excellently composed with the obvious retro chiptune sound, but keeps a fine balance of high intensity hooks and bittersweet nostalgia.

I did try it out almost 10 years ago but never got very far, and with this review I decided I should return to it as I knew it had obtained quite a cult following. This said, it is not my intent to in any way disrespect those that hold the game in a high regard, but more so give a different take on an already established title and a greater understanding for games in general. Claiming video games are art is a very derogatory approach that revolves around putting the art label on anything that evokes emotion or is close to heart. As in my take, however beautiful a team synergy can be in football it should not be classified as an art because the intent of the practice is at it's core competitive and not reflective, which is inherently the same case with a lot of video games and most notable the earlier we go. As the medium of games has evolved from tabletop interactions to arcade blasters, it entered the digital age. But it always revolved around overcoming obstacles and achieving a goal, hence the competitive side. I would never say that Pac-Man is art, nor would I say that League of Legends is art. But in the wake of creation, much in the same vein of the evolution of moving pictures, the interactivity of games has truly reached the capabilities of an art form such as cinema, music or painting.

Immersion in visuals and audio is a powerful force that conspire with you as a person, which prompts an active process where the object resonates with the subject instead of being a one-sided interaction. The gameplay on the other hand are mostly set up by rules which you abide to, where the mechanics communicate with you what you should or need to know. The multimodality of visuals and audio can instead be told by you (the player) what it should mean, because it is all up to the perception of the medium.

Gameplay in itself is not art, but the visuals and audio is, and more so the fusion that is exemplified in a coherent product. VVVVVV is a take on the 80s arcade games, and is by design "gameplay only" while the visuals acts as the carriage for said gameplay. What do I want to say with this? It is not my objective to label VVVVVV through a certain criteria, but I rather explain how the intent of the game can be understood as nothing short of a redundant rearview mirror. Leaving the gameplay to the side, VVVVVV functions best as a nostalgia trip but is through it a sorry impression of a gone by time. A time when games operated by the means of limitations in technology and not intellectual property. VVVVVV doesn't try to be anything else than a retro fling when so many games in the same age took giant leaps for the indie scene. This doesn't invalidate the developer's work and the strive of the indie company, but only exemplifies the hollowness of VVVVVV when standing next to titles that were released the same year (2010), such as Super Meat Boy (which is another difficult retro platformer) or more cerebral and slow-paced games like LIMBO. This said, VVVVVV still works as an arcade game that is appreciated for the satisfaction of "winning", but that is not why I play games.

88119404.review:
This certainly is an interesting game. I like the mechanics, being able to flip instead of jump is a really interesting idea. The fact that I paid $5 and got 8 hours out of this game, during which I fully %100'd it twice (once normally, once in Flip mode), and I don't have nearly all the achievements really goes to show the insane replay value they managed to cram into this little indie game from 10 years ago now.

The graphical style is great, I've always been a sucker for "retro" graphics. What amazes me is that they went the whole 9 yards in that styling. Most games with a "retro" style seem to just use pixel art and not really bother with what made the old games so impressive: limitation. But VVVVVV goes the extra mile with the Commodore 64 style. Text boxes adhere to the color cells, all the music could be achieved using a S.I.D. chip (although maybe not during gameplay), and even the sprites for the characters are spot-on period-correct, their eyes and mouth hollow because for a majority of the game, you're on a black "space" background. Little nods to tricks like that used to save memory on the old systems really bring the nerd in me out. Also, nice touch with the cassette turbo-loader when the game boots ;)

All those little details are what really drive the retro style home for me. Games like Shovel Knight and Cave Story, while great in terms of their gameplay, don't really adhere to the limitations that bred creativity back in the day. They just use pixel art and call it a day, maybe with a few low-frame animations thrown in too. Truth is, even VVVVVV breaks those limitations sometimes, namely with the background in outer space, because the background normally can't move on a C64 (at least, not without some serious programming wizardry)

Alright, enough gushing about the style. What about the gameplay? Well, it's a mixture of puzzle-platformer and just raw platformer, with maybe a teensy pinch of Metroid thrown in. And I love it. All those little trinkets to collect, clearing out the entire map, the time trials mode, flipped mode, all sorts of extra things to do on top of the main game, which is admittedly short. Just saving all your fellow crewmates, a skilled player could expect to beat the game in an hour or two. While most trinkets are just a quick little side-path away and won't take up too much time, some (namely the ones on Space Station 2) can be extraordinarily difficult, the most infamous of which being in a room called "Doing things the hard way" with a Terminal that taunts you.

I already touched on the Music in the Graphics segment, but bottom line, if you like Shovel Knight's music (or  S.I.D. demo-scene music, or just chiptunes in general) you'll like the stuff here too. It's great.

For $5 you could certainly get worse, VVVVVV is not a bad choice by any means. It's heaps of fun, albeit short. But if you're into user-created content and mods, there is a built-in level editor!

You've had 10 years to buy the game. DO IT!!

86988841.review:
VVVVVV is the first game in a very long time that I've actually felt genuine excitement to play each day. The graphics are standard minimalistic retro style, and the story is a little generic, but decent, but what really stands out to me in this game is the gameplay. It is SO much fun. I have played this game for extensive amounts of time without getting bored, and that's a rarity for me, because I have quite a short attention span. This game is pretty hard, but the difficulty is a bit overrated if you ask me. I beat it in a mere 4 days, which was not something I expected to happen so quickly. That's not to say that this game isn't difficult, though. I died at least once on almost every single room, and at least 50 times on every level. This game is challenging, but fair. Not a single room felt like it was unfairly difficult, and only one of the twenty trinkets felt that way for me. (*ahem* Edge Games *ahem*) Even the infamous Doing Things The Hard Way, which is probably one of the hardest levels in gaming history, never got old or stale for me, even though I died at least 500 times there and spent almost 2 hours on it. (It was more enjoyable than Edge Games, that's for sure.)

And don't even get me started on the OST. It is absolutely phenomenal. Every song is memorable in its own way, and none of them sound too similar to each other. Each one fits the level it plays in extremely well, and I'll definitely be downloading every song. Out of all of them, Positive Force is probably my favorite, but it's pretty hard to choose.

Not sure if I'll ever be able to 100% this, but I'll certainly try, because this game is addicting. I've found myself playing the time trials over and over again to S-rank them, and I've been doing it for hours and hours on end without them getting boring once. I've even started speedrunning it, and I always used to think that speedrunning was boring and pointless, but this game makes it really fun somehow. don't know what it is about this game that makes playing the same levels over and over again so much fun, but something about this game has that wonderful quality, which is good, because there's a lot of that.

Overall, this game is challenging, but it's easily one of the most fun gaming experiences of my entire life, and I would recommend it to anyone who has the skill level.

85593403.review:
As far as puzzle platformers go, VVVVVV is a real brain twister.

I am impressed with a lot of the concepts behind this game.  The minimalistic visuals belie a game with very engaging puzzles and complex level designs.  The difficulty level of the puzzles can increase drastically as you progress through areas, which often have their own technical quirks that deftly utilize the game's mechanics in unique and interesting combinations.  They can be challenging and even outright hard, but they're never completely impossible.

*As of Jan 29, 2021 less than 15% of players have completed the base game at all, disregarding item collection, overall map completion, number of deaths, etc.*

While the characters are not always the most nuanced, they all have their own personalities and a variety of interactions can take place.  The game's simple, yet driving digital soundtrack is very fitting to the setting in which this all takes place, and generally compliments the game's aesthetic as a whole.  (Full disclosure: I'm still listening to it as I'm writing this review.)  The room names, while usually thought provoking, can also be humorous and even trolly at times.  It's enjoyable to see this cerebral of a game have moments where it also doesn't take itself too seriously.  No spoilers here, it'll make sense if/when you read the credits.

These are all things which add up to a game that, although minimalistc by design, is greater than the sum of its parts.  My playthrough finished in just under 1100 deaths, so it's doubtful at best that I could pass the No Death Challenge.  However, I plan on revisiting this game a bit to at least fully explore the map while enjoying the groovy soundtrack and some of the more difficult (read: engaging!) puzzles again.

Although this game can and will infuriate at times (Your Bitter Tears... Delicious), the satisfaction of solving these complex puzzles generally outweighs whatever frustration is felt in the moment.  However, if you're expecting VVVVVV to be as merciful as say, a Mario game, you will either be delightfully surprised or sorely mistaken, depending on perspective.  Should one choose to pay attention, it's possible to begin understanding what happened to this dimension and the reasons behind its bizarre physical properties.  It's not absolutely necessary, but to me it was a nice glimpse into the game and its internal logic.

All in all, as a supporter of indie games and a fan of physics and puzzles in general, I recommend checking out VVVVVV as a generally amusing and cerebral experience.

Cheers!

85538883.review:
I don't get why this game has been referred to as a "rage game". A rage game is a game where every obstacle is placed completely unfairly, the controls are sloppy and either too stiff, too slippery or somehow both and all of the levels and areas are horrifically designed. 

This game is filled with incredibly hard yet fair challenges, excellently well designed levels and super snappy controls. Oh and also a cool cast of characters, a minimalist but still great looking art style and a small yet amazing soundtrack (which you can buy on bandcamp by the way. The album is called PPPPPP).

I've bought this game, no joke, 3 times. I bought it first for the 3DS and managed to beat it after 3000 deaths and around 10 hours of total gameplay (at age 11 and I'm still proud). Then when my 3DS broke, I bought it on PS4 and beat it in 3 hours with 500 deaths. Then I discovered that the PC version had a level editor so that I could make and install custom levels, so I bought it again. 

If you're not good at the game, you'll have fun trying to get the precise movements of each room down because the infinite lives and frequent checkpoints allow for extensive experimentation. But if you're good at the game, you have the opportunity to play the game over and over again because, if you're good, you can beat it in under an hour. And then when you get REALLY good, you can access the replays of different intermission sections and the time trials of the main areas, play until you can beat every single challenged the game has on offer without dying once, and then go for the mystical "Master of the Universe" trophy which is only unlocked once you've beaten the entire game without dying once.

It's fun, it's challenging, it's short and it's cheap. Play it. 8.8/10

VVVVVV is a platformer in the style of old school 80's games. It's defining mechanic is that instead of jumping, the player flips upside down. The developer has done a great job utilizing this unique aspect of the game and it shows in it's outstanding level design. VVVVVV is definitely a tough game to beat however. You'll almost be certain to have hundreds if not thousands of deaths the first time you play. But the difficulty is authentic and almost never throws something unfair at the player, with enough practice the player can master these obstacles and eventually you'll see your death count go down in subsequent playthoughs. While not necessarily complex or lengthy, the story does it's job of building the world and plot enough were the player has a good idea of what's going on around them. Awesome soundtrack and retro aesthetic. Challenging but not punishing (the checkpoints are quite generous). Main story never seemed impossible, just takes many tries to get right (and a lot of deaths—it's telling that the easiest "complete the game with less than X deaths" achievement is 500). The main mechanic is flipping and nothing else, not even jumping, which makes for a unique experience (especially when it comes to level design) and is very satisfying. 

The main story is quite short, but the game has a lot of replayability in its extra modes (such as time trials) and is nice to just pick up and play a little of at a time.

75717801.review:
Genre:
-Precision Platformer w/ some exploration

Fit for me:
-Perfect fit for me

Pros:
-The gravity flipping mechanic was extremely innovative when this game was released
-Well designed world to explore that works really well w/ the platforming sections
-20 Secrets available that add another layer of challenge for those that want it
-A couple of end game modes like 1 life mode and Time Trials
-Really easy to learn
-Very cheap at $5 and on sale all the time
-It feel like you are a part of a cohesive world, and not just a bunch of independent platforming sections

Cons:
-Very slick movement, you slide a lot
-It's quite rough around the edges on the visuals and may turn some players off even before getting started
-The gravity flipping mechanic has a pretty steep learning curve to just become semicompetent
-Really easy to get lost and the map isn't very intuitive
-Not a ton of variation in environmental hazards, obstacles, or platforming sections

Thoughts:
-VVVVVV was created during a time when very few indie games were being developed. It didn't receive the financial success that the devs would have liked, but over the last 10 years, it's picked up a cult following.  It's now a game recommended to anyone that really likes precision platformers.  After playing this, it's very clear that developers today have taken inspiration from VVVVVV.  It shows it's age and is pretty rough around the edges, but it's still a fun experience even in 2020.

Consensus:
-Middle of the Road Game (Tier 4 and makes up 25% of my reviews).  Solid world building, exploration, and hard but fair platforming gauntlets make this a good choice for platforming fans.  However, it hasn't aged well over the last 10 years, and it shows.  I think it's an easy recommendation when on sale, but it doesn't have the type of polish that Celeste, The End is Nigh, N++, etc have, so take that into consideration.

73470153.review:
VVVVVV  is a lazy retro pixel 2D platformer, one of literally thousands of retro pixel games infesting the Steam store.  Negotiate a number of levels using the oh-so-original gravity inversion mechanism (and not much else), you can progress through all the puzzle levels and learn new levels of spite for the sheer lack of quality that is the "indie" gaming movement. 

As a game, existing on the Steam store, this falls far beneath what anyone would describe as "State of the Art".  The effort that went into the game is directly proportional to the effort the developer put into naming the game.   "VVVVVVV", indeed.  The game uses lazy retro pixel graphics because the developer lacked the talent or budget to arrange 3D, high definition computer graphics.   The developer was unable/incapable of providing variable resolution, despite being released in 2010.  The developer was incapable of arranging a game that displays properly in 16:9 resolution, despite being released in 2010, the game displays in 4:3 pillarboxed, completely unacceptable in this decade, or the last one. 

The developer charges $7.50 for this game, which exceeds the price of games like Skyrim, Shadow of Mordor, Just Cause 3 and dozen of other, older AAA games, yet unlike those exceptional games, features 4:3 aspect ratio, fixed resolution and ugly pixel graphics.   If there was ever a case that Steam should be purged of games that fail to meet basic quality standards, VVVVVV would be Exhibit A.  Do not buy this rubbish.

72935767.review:
VVVVVV is a quirky but enjoyable little game with some interesting flipping game mechanics. It's a platformer, but only in the strictest sense. Your character does not jump, but instead changes the pull of gravity. The action button launches you in the opposite direction and you will keep going until hitting an obstacle. This could be on the same screen or through a large part of the map. This makes exploring the map a unique experience. The goal is to locate your crew and teleport them back to the ship. There are also 20 shiny trinkets scattered around the map, which are optional, but provide a welcome challenge and some replay value.

What I liked:
- The graphics. I am a sucker for the old school aesthetic. This looks like it could have been a C64 game.
- The audio. The music was pretty good, and there are additional background tracks to unlock. While it was a little repetitive, it never became annoying. The minimal sound effects add to the retro feel.
- Stats. The game tracks your number of deaths and time of completion, giving it some replay value.
-Room names. Naming each room was a nice touch.

What could have been better:
- Game length. The main game was pretty short. I was able to complete the main objective and get most of the trinkets in less than 4 hours. However, there is replay value in going back to get the last few trinkets, play through the Time Trials, and explore user created levels.
-Hit detection. Sometimes it feels like you should clear the spikes, but it is counted as a death. Nothing egregious, it just requires pixel perfect timing in some rooms.

Overall, I recommend this game if it's on sale. I wouldn't consider it a "must have" title, but it's a fun and challenging way to spend an afternoon.

72541993.review:
V V V V V V

VVVVVV is a short, indie platformer where you play as Captain Virdian. Your crew was teleported and you have to find them and take them back to the ship. Will you succeed? What will you encounter during your adventure? Will you rage? Play the game and find out.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
What do I mean by rage? Do you see the word "Difficult" the list of tags for this game?
Hahahahahaha. Well...
This game is short but very hard. It will take a lot of trial and error and many deaths for you to beat the game...
Unless you are a king at games like this and can beat it without dying once. If you can, I'll give you my respect.
Anyway, the music is great. I really like the music in this game. Back to the difficulty, this game will challenge you with all of the obstacles that you come across. And that one part with a lot of trial and error for a trinket Virdian can get to since a small block is blocking it...
HELP ME!!!

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
Since the game is difficult, it isn't for everyone. There will be some moments that you might just rage quit the game. In my eyes, it isn't for a casual gamer. Another issue I had is how Viridian controls. It feels like he is slippery, and moments where I finally reached a certain place, only for him to move a little bit into some spikes were frustrating. While this game is short, it uses that time to challenge you. From the story to the challenges from the achievements, this game will use its time to test you.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I'll recommend VVVVVV ONLY to those that are looking for a challenge. If you get mad easily, step away from this game. It has nice music and a lot of replayability. Since it's short, maybe you would want to test yourself to not die as much as you did on your last try? I know I will. Almost 1000 deaths from my first time completing the game...
Whew. That's not good.

72140889.review:
It's fine.

Although VVVVVV initially might seem to center challenge as a platformer with some unique mechanics, VVVVVV seems to be partially inspired by minimalist exploration platformer games like Seiklus and Knytt in its overall game structure. All of its "levels" are actually part of a connected world, and part of the game is navigating those spaces.

However, while the VVVVVV's platforming challenges are creative and exciting, the overall game world isn't particularly interesting to explore, with a lot of underdesigned empty space. I think that a more conventional level based approach would have been a stronger choice for the game structure.

72059740.review: What Terry Cavanagh's masterpiece of a platformer lacks in plot, it more than makes up for in the mechanics of its platforming. [i]VVVVVV[/i] packs an arduous (though never unfair) challenge, with a surprising level of visual beauty. Beat it once, and it is tempting to never tackle it again, but that would be to miss out on the greater challenges which the game provides. This is probably not true but I've always regarded the bizarre sad elephant room to be a reference to Terry A. Davis' elephant in TempleOS; this Easter egg and the charming naming of the rooms are two of my favourite things about the game. "Kids His Age Bounce", "I Love You/That's Why I Have to Kill You", and "The Warning" (prior to Veni Vidi Vici) are a few standout names to me. Also, I must give credit to Cavanagh for including accessibility options for disabled players, an incredibly based decision which most developers tend to overlook.

71256045.review:
I'm trying very, very hard to enjoy this game. I like difficult platformers. Been playing a lot of LOVE lately, and Super Meat Boy is also a personal favorite of mine. 

So where does this game go wrong? It's difficulty comes almost entirely from being unfair. I've only played for half an hour and this is what I've come across. Lot's of blind jumps that will have you dying over and over because the last solid ground was 3 screens back. Lines that auto flip you work in a strange way. And one of the biggest things is how you have momentum and don't come to a complete stop the second you stop pressing a direction. This is almost always bad in difficult platformers that require precision. Especially in a game with so many blind jumps. 

Part of what makes it difficult, compared to other difficult platformers I've played, is that the camera is mostly locked to the screen. So you will often have to make a blind jump, go to the next screen, and pray you are on track to go to the next screen. This is just downright unfair. Trial and error gameplay isn't difficult. It's just unfair. What's worse is that there are sections were the camera does follow you. And yet somehow, at least one of those sections also manages to have blind jumps in it. 

Want an idea of just how hard the game is? Just look at the achievements and percentages. Only 4% of players have beat the game with less than 500 deaths. And that's the 3rd most common achievement. And there's an achievement for beating the game without dying at all!? [spoiler] I'm sure I'll go for it eventually [/spoiler]

So what does this game do right? Quite a lot actually. It's cheap. The music is awesome. The story is engaging enough for the type of game it is. There's a large map to explore, with sections that act more like actual levels. The graphics are great. 

I have to recommend against getting it though, as the main part of the game is the game play, and it just isn't fair. It's trial and error gameplay disguising itself as difficulty. If you don't care about achievements or unfair difficulty, give the game a try. It's still a great game. It's just the unfair difficulty that's the problem.

First of all, this game might as well be a masterpiece for some, if it wasnt so enjoyable for me doesnt mean you cant like it.

The game has solid soundtrack and elegant in a simplistic way graphics, reminding of gaming in ages gone, the core mechanic of the game is that instead of jumping your character inverts gravity, which leads to a very original way of making and solving platforming challenges, but sometimes it is hard for me and my simplistic brain to keep up and i often stoped thinking with the "invert gravity" mindset, turning the gameplay confusing at times.

Until about half way through the game is a joy to play and exploring the map is fun if a bit confusing, but there is a point where the game presents you with a intermission that breaks pacing of exploration and put you into the worst type of scouting mission i have seen in a while, and from that point on every intermission was increasingly frustrating to a point the game became a chore for me

After i finally finished the game i went to take a look at the achievements and holy shit, i never seen such impossible looking achievements in a game. I mean, the whole point of the game is that it gets hard but its ok because you die and is put imediatly back with literally zero downtime, so expect to die hundreds or thousants of times, however there is an achievement for beating the game without dying a single time, which while very possible, is very much against the game design in my opinion and that puts me off trying to do it at all.

All in all the game might as well be very good for some, it looks goods and sounds really good, i wish i liked it more.

70696406.review: There's a real sense of discovery that comes with this world.  You feel so lost in the beginning, just being introduced to the gravity mechanic, you will likely be swept to places you didn't intend, and can stumble upon what sometimes feels like a limitless void.  You feel lost, and almost homesick for the station you started on.  But eventually you'll find some indoor sections, and begin the platforming part of the game.  These sections are really fun, and each screen is different and distinct, there is defenitely quality over quantity in the platforming.  They're defenitely challenging, but I wouldn't say to the level that it will make you rage.  There's a great sense of accomplishment when you complete these, and each ends in a great gauntlet that test's you on what you learn.  And once you've completed some of these, you start to feel more comfortable traversing the world, everything you've learned in the platforming starts to make the entire void feel like your home.  So I defenitely reccomend this game, but the one hiccup I might point out is that it can feel like the game gets easier overtime, not just traversing the world (I mean that's why I love the game) but in the platforming itself.  You can easily do the hardest level first, and then everything else feels like a breeze. All in all though its a great game.

It's a fun, indie game. Relatively short, easy to beat in one or two sittings.

The simplicity of the game is what makes it a lot of fun. It's just a normal platformer but remove the jump, replace it with flip gravity. Yet it still feels unique enough to be worth giving a go.

This game is [i]sorta[/i] the type to make you rage, but not really. It's only a handful of trinkets (optional collectibles that contain most of the game's difficulty, the base game itself isn't that hard honestly. Especially with the game handing checkpoints to you at every turn and corner, it doesn't feel unfair when you die and have to start from your last checkpoint.

The music is really good at setting the mood for the game. It's the other thing keeping you calm as you keep dying over and over again lol. The retro feel of the game is welcomed as well, usually a great fit for many indie games, this game certainly being no exception.

I would recommend this game for anyone looking for something that offers a fun challenge while still being a game you can sit back and relax while playing.

And for those who like pain followed by a nice reward, try to get all 20 trinkets.

69184225.review:
It's pretty much a game for nobody, and I'm confused how platform-lovers can get into this.

You side-scroll at an intervalled pace, a single keystroke pushing you X distance -- so one wrong button press and its hasta la vista off a cliff, or into a baddie.  
The 'jump' action is replaced by a "flip" that puts you walking on the ceiling, then another "flip" puts you back on the floor, etc. -- so the map's obstacles must be countered on two parallel planes.
The game uses static screens, so you aren't smooth-moving like Mario -- at least in as much as I played.
The result is a timing puzzle that resets with each new screen entry.  So, mostly, you just learn the trick to that area and run it until you pass that screen.

It's crap.

68377341.review:
So, VVVVVV is a challenging platformer with simple controls.  Don’t let my time fool you, I’ve played closer to about 5 hours total.  My first time playing this was with a friend on their account.  We took turns and our original adventure through this game ended on a bad note.  We rage quit at a difficult room (that escort mission is annoying – I hate the mechanics behind it).  We overall had a fun but frustrating time with the game, and I had no desire to return to this...  until I got it at part of a bundle.
Coming back to it, most of the game mechanics and challenges came back to me pretty quickly and I proceeded to beat it in an hour and a half.  Obviously, I hadn’t seen the entire game up to this point, but I feel like I saw most of what the game has to offer as far as it’s tricks and gimmicks.  
I would say round 2 went better – it was an overall better experience with the game.  Fun but I do have some issues with the it.  
I think overall, I would say this is a good game.  Length wise, I don’t know if it’s worth the five dollars.  But that’s also coming from someone who’s probably actually spent closer to five hours total on this game, so take my advice with a grain of salt.
If it looks your style. go and get it.  What you see is what you get with this.
Gameplay wise, this game is a mixed bag of mostly fun and a little frustrating.  This game is full of hard challenges that are not for the basic gamer, the week of spirit who need to get gud.  Yeah - Casual gamers probably won’t find as much enjoyment out of this.  You’ll probably have some fun then get stuck somewhere difficult and rage quit, I should know because it happened to me and my friend.  The game does try to be a bit more forgiving with no lives in this game and multiple checkpoint which are very much appreciated.  you can die as many times as you want, no penalty.  Though, I think hard level design wasn’t really where my rage moments came from - I think a fair amount of my frustration seems to come from the physics in the game.  The character is slippery, so I’ve skidded into spikes many many times.  I’d do something right but went a little too fast – fly into spikes or skid into spikes and have to do it again (with similar results probably).  It happened a lot.  
And then that escort mission.  Skidding + a clone of you always following five paces behind + no mercy = frustration.  This part sucks, even revisiting it I still found it fairly annoying.  
Don’t get the wrong idea, though.  Yes, the frustrations stick out like a sore thumb, but most of the game is very fun.  I like the ideas here and it’s well executed for the most part which made me feel engrossed in the adventure – even with the graphics the way they are. I think it was a fun little romp to revisit and it was worth my time.   I never started to question why I was even playing this game, a feeling I have with frustrating games or repetitive/empty games.  It engrossed me and I enjoyed it – most of it.  Would recommend for people who like what they see or want a challenge.

66762409.review:
First of all, this game is not super long. You can finish a first playthrough in about 90 minutes. However in this case that doesn't matter: the game is cheap and it has a good replay value, even though you always play the same map. 

What replay value is there? First of all there are the achievements. The base game is not super easy, but these achievements make it a whole lot harder. For example, there are time trails, where you need to finish sections perfectly (0 death and all trinkets, all in a certain time). There is also a lab with a Super Gravitron, where you need to dodge square bullets. This is also super challenging. 

The game mechanic is smart: a platformer where you can't jump but only flip gravity, and I think this idea is executed very nicely. There is also a map editor if you want to create some challenges yourself, but I didn't get bored yet, so I haven't tried that :)

Buy it, it's worth the money (except if you get frustrated really easily :p)!

62355201.review:
[i]VVVVVV[/i] is an amazing game!

It is challenging, but not [i]too[/i] difficult - it has a perfect balance of easiness and hardness. It is fun, and has a neat storyline. The music is great and very fitting.

Although it is a short game, you will have fun all the way through. Sometimes I got frustrated while playing it, but it never lasted too long. It's not a game where you will spend [i]tons[/i] of time on one section, and I think that's good.

I really like the graphics. I don't think the game would work better with any other graphics.

I'm sure that there are lots of challenges you can set for yourself with this game to get more value out of it - for example, speedrunning, getting all the shiny trinkets, getting all the achievements (although the no deaths one seems [i]really[/i] hard), etc. I wouldn't be surprised if some people have spent tens or hundreds of hours playing this game.

There isn't really much else to say. Just buy the game! It seems pretty cheap for how fun it is!

61819915.review:
Incredibly fun yet brutal, VVVVVV is an interesting minimalist twitch-platformer.  Death is frequent, often a mere microsecond away in timing (with some challenges feeling outright malicious), but a fast respawn and a very catchy soundtrack keep the game flowing smoothly.  Skilled players could probably beat the game in an hour or two (I am not a skilled player), but there is plenty of replay value with additional game modes, custom levels, and trinket collecting.  Though simple, the art is consistent and looks great (especially with the additional filters---though the distortions effects absolutely make the game more difficult), the writing is lighthearted and witty, and the aforementioned soundtrack is among the best chiptune music I've listened to.

Overall, one of my favorite platformers.  If you enjoy a challenge or are just looking for a fun game to casually jump into after a long day, I highly recommend VVVVVV.

60601457.review:
VVVVVV is a 2D platformer in which the core mechanic is reversal of gravity being above or below.

Despite its short duration, VVVVVV manages to introduce a nice amount of different gameplay mechanics for the player to figure out. With these mechanics being relatively simple, and checkpoints being provided to the player at an (in my opinion) excessive rate, clearing the levels in this game is not much of a challenge.

The simplistic visual art left more to be desired, but the soundtrack more than made up for it. With a collection of several excellent tracks that the player can select between, exploration becomes infinitely more enjoyable.

The story aspect is very minimal, which is somewhat normal in this genre. I would be pleased with more of a narrative, but I will not fault the lack of it.

If you are interested in a short casual platformer with retro style, this game is for you. If you are more interested complex and difficult games in the same genre, stylistic successors of this game (Super Meat Boy, Celeste, to name a few prominent ones) might be up your alley.

Although I have enjoyed many other games in the same genre as VVVVVV substantially more, the groovy soundtrack and well executed core mechanics left me with an overall positive experience.

6/10

59871590.review:
Just bought this game after wishing for it since 2010, I was a wee 6-year-old then, I'm 15 now and it still holds the charm today that the flash demo did all that time ago!

Strong points:
Replayability: This game is open-ended which allows for at least 120 different playthroughs because nothing is locked behind anything else except for the intermissions, the final level and 2 trinkets, the first you get by talking a bunch and I won't spoil the other!
Graphics: The retro graphics are far from being an eyesore, in fact there's only 4 rooms in which there is a chance of a seizure and you can leave those rooms pretty quickly... or you can stay in any of those four for a secret
Community: Although it's no longer as active, the community is usually pretty chillax, you can check out the forums for a backlog of levels or you can check out the discord to talk to people who are also in the community!

Weak Points:
Graphics: The retro graphics seem a tad overused to some. and there is the elephant in the (4) room(s) to mention.
Controls: The controls are slippery, but these ARE a step up from the first alpha

Difficulty: Depends
With trinkets: Hard, there are two main offending trinkets and they are BOTH from the longest level.
Without trinkets: Medium, the level design is not easy, but it doesn't get as bad as a certain two trinkets or I Wanna be The Guy

Would I recommend: Yes.
Just because it's old doesn't mean it's bad, it's aged well in nine years

58359337.review:
If at first you don't succeed: die, die, die again. VVVVVV is a puzzle platformer that uses a simple, retro interface and a few basic mechanics to create an experience that cannot be described as merely challenging. No, it is teeth-grindingly, eyeball-bleedingly HARD. If you have a good deal of patience and a reasonable level of control over your blood-pressure, then there is little more cathartic than finally beating a particularly challenging room -- only for the next room to bend you over a pommel-horse and start wailing on your backside with equal fervor as the one before.

The story of VVVVVV is competent, but not spectacular. What we are primarily here for is to bash our head against a wall for the sheer, mad joy of seeing whether it or our skull will give out first.

54496005.review:
VVVVVV is an incredible game.

All the music is absolutely amazing, with every song unique and enjoyable. I never disliked any song, and they fit perfectly into the section they were played in.
The graphics combined with the difficult gameplay reminds me of an nes game, and the music compliments such. 
Story and lore is mostly displayed through "monitors" that are mostly on the path, so you can choose to stop and read them if you want to. This makes it feel more like you're an explorer, which is nice.
No upgrades and the ability to freely explore make the game much more fun.

But

The gameplay get incredibly difficult in certain sections, you can't look ahead and instead have to make leaps of faith, and many of the trinkets are unbelievably hard to get to. You never really get an ending, even if you complete everything, (dunno about getting all the achievements) so it feels like you never really beat the game. 

Overall a very good game with some times you may want to throw the controller.

54479273.review: Fun little game! Makes great use of the gravity gimmick, has catchy music, and the levels are pretty fun! It has a lot of replay value, as there is no set path you must go to rescue all of the crew members, and there's a level editor, as well as plenty of community-made levels to keep you playing. Definitely play it if you haven't!

54156124.review:
After 101 hours and getting all 19 achievements, I absolutely hate this game. During my first run of this game, I didn't really enjoy it that much, but it was a game. One of the first steam games I ever played. And I'm glad I played it so that my experience could only get better. This was originally crowned as a rage game, and personally I think that label is stupid. It's not designed to be unfair, although it is for reasons I won't be going into because of how much else I have to rant about. It's not hard by any means, and yes, you will die plenty, but that doesn't make it hard. The progress you'll lose is minuscule, and you'll be able to get back to where ever you died in seconds. There's only a few screens you'll get stuck on for a while unless you go for the trinkets. Even then, it'll never be that bad.

However, now we get to the completionist side of things. The achievement for getting 1 minute in the super gravitron SUCKED. GOOD GOD IT SUCKED. I don't mean that it's hard, though it is, I mean that it took me literal years to finish because it was so stupidly boring and hypnotizing, and I had such little desire to actually finish it, that this game is somehow my longest project ever. I left this game and came back to it at least 6 times, with several month long breaks between. There will be plenty of times where you'll die and have absolutely no say in the matter. You'll start losing interest fast when you're on you longest run yet, and die from pure rng. Thing is, that's not the worst achievement. Beating the game deathless. Is a thing. This is a game that has no right to have an achievement like that. It's so, so, so boring. The levels themselves are insanely easy when you've beaten them 20 times. You'll still die to them because you weren't paying any attention because of shear boredom, but you'll never die because it was hard. That is, until TWELVE minutes into the run. Imagine trying to no hit a boss that has a twelve minute cutscene at the start. That's what you're signing up for. Also the final level is aids.

Here's my deathless video where I reviewed the game in more detail if I haven't convinced you not to play this yet. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YWgbe6Fh7WQ

The game is only about 2 hours, but there's optional trinkets to be found, and you can find great replay value from time trials or just trying to beat the game with as few deaths or in as little time as possible (I have played this game for over 100 hours on 3DS). The soundtrack is fantastic.

What on the surface looked like a cheap and simple game turned out to be an awkward mess.

It starts off straightforward enough - a basic story, basic puzzles, but then quickly starts relying on good short term memory for progress, and opens up into a huge area that seems devoid of objectives.

As you fall into the next stages you have to remember to instantly move to one side or the other, and how far to move, as your character falls towards fatal objects.

If there was just another moment before you fell to your death then the skill of quick reactions could come into play, but lacking that; it's only appealing to those with good short term memory.

★☆☆☆☆

51046100.review:
Very fun game, would recommend to anyone who enjoys 2D platformers.

The only possible downsides would be the graphical style, and simple storytelling, which may have been off-putting to some. I think they quickly became quite charming, the story is cute, and not meant to be taken too seriously; you get used to the low pixel count, and some of the areas are actually quite pretty.

[*] The main mechanic is utilised quite well, new mechanics are added at a good pacing, and elaborated on as much as necessary until a new one is introduced (they are all awesome btw). 
[*] Level design is great, and the secrets are hidden just well enough to make you feel clever, while still being very accessible. To top it off you even get a map of them once you complete the story (which every game needs imo). 
[*] Exploration is very liberating, soon as you start the game, pretty much the entire map is available to explore, which is very big, and very open. Watching the map increase in size by 10 units at a time is very satisfying, and makes your progress very obvious.
[*] The game is fairly short, it took me 1:59:59 to beat it with most of the medals (I scraped up the last few afterwards). This works in its favour though, because the game it just so dense with gameplay; its a blast the whole way through.
[*] There are achievements and minigames to unlock after gathering the collectables. I only dipped me toe in them, but wasn't very interested in sinking my time into them. All in all, still a good addition for other players.

50844187.review:
A fun, colorful little arcade romp through challenging 2d spaces with one simple game mechanic to get you through it all: pressing space, you invert your alien sprite to go up or down.  Took around 1.5 hours to beat without collecting anything or doing the time modes.  Loved the creativity in the levels.  Great to replay.

(Updated 6/2) I've since beaten the game a few times.  Familiar with the layout, it's possible to beat VVVVVV in under 30 minutes and the levels become easier.  I had an easier time playing with a game controller (using the + directional pad) than the control stick or the keyboard.  

For achievement hunters, getting all the achievements in this is impossible.  Many people cheat to get the Super Gravitron achievement and the one with 0 deaths.    There are even guides telling you how to cheat.  Frowning at that.

Wanted to update for my photo sensitive friends that there's a big elephant in the room with this game that will set you off.  Thankfully there is an option in the first menu (game options - accessibility options) where you can toggle off the flashing colors/lights to an extent.  Just be warned.

The soundtrack by Magnus Pallson only serves to add to the trancelike oddysey through a world of neon space, where you are challenged to think quickly and laterally to progress. The only gripes that could be had are the handful of bugs that are more amusing than harmful, and the relatively light story, but these only serve to add to the game's charm. For a short, challenging and delightfully retro romp, you could do so, so much worse for the asking price here. Highly recommended.

I love this game. It's such a simple concept but it can be extremely, extremely challenging.

I found out about this game from watching people speedrun it at GDQ, and I have to say that I'm even more impressed by them now after playing it for myself and dying over and over.

It's a relatively small world, you move from screen to screen, which all vary in difficulty and connection. There are a ton of treasures that can be found, but are hard to reach.

It's fun using different mechanics like gravity flips, same-screen puzzles, and teleports. For casuals, speedrunners, and perfectionists alike it's fun to play at least once for the price.

I rescued all but 1 crew member before I got stuck and quit playing. Each section of the map holds different mechanics and puzzles, and I can't seem to find the last one.

Awesome example of simple concepts and indie games done right.

50383580.review: This is easily a modern platforming classic and it's not hard to see why it's a speedrunning staple. The gameplay is a mild challenge... unless you decide to find all the Trinkets, in which case the challenge (and number of deaths) really ramps up. The art and music perfectly evoke the old consoles, and the game comes with some filters to make you feel like you're playing on an old CRT. That said, one graphics option randomly scrolls the screen up every so often, and while realistic it is extremely distracting - but that's really the only negative. The game might feel a little short if you didn't try to collect everything, but the time trials, challenges new game mode and custom levels provide plenty of replayability. At its price the game is an absolute steal; every platformer fan should own this game.
